body:
Here is an outline how it can be done, because there is no additional dependency besides blas, it should be quite identical to what was given
- [ ] Use the amalgamation script https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/tree/master/amalgamation to create a C library
- [ ] Find a blas library in IOS, openblas or other blas, to link and create a C library `libmxnet_predict.so`
- [ ] Create a swift/object-c wrapper, that calls https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/include/mxnet/c_predict_api.h
  - The call is only a foreign C call, so should be easy for both language
  - You can ref other wrappers such as https://github.com/jdeng/gomxnet/ on how to call C API
- You  should be good to go

I wrote a model base class and a solver base class for autoencoder training under example/autoencoder/model.py & example/autoencoder/solver.py 
You can have a look.
It also supports printing internal activation for debugging

I will fix this soon.

```
File "example\\numpy-ops\\numpy_softmax.py", line 48, in <module>
mlp = mysoftmax(data=fc3, name = 'softmax')
File "C:\Users\sxjscience\AppData\Roaming\Python\Python27\site-packages\mxnet-0.5.0-py2.7.egg\mxnet\operator.py", line 23, in __call__
return self.get_symbol(*args, **kwargs)
File "C:\Users\sxjscience\AppData\Roaming\Python\Python27\site-packages\mxnet-0.5.0-py2.7.egg\mxnet\operator.py", line 207, in get_symbol
**kwargs)
File "C:\Users\sxjscience\AppData\Roaming\Python\Python27\site-packages\mxnet-0.5.0-py2.7.egg\mxnet\symbol.py", line 798, in creator
ctypes.byref(sym_handle)))
File "C:\Users\sxjscience\AppData\Roaming\Python\Python27\site-packages\mxnet-0.5.0-py2.7.egg\mxnet\base.py", line 73, in check_call

mxnet.base.MXNetError: Invalid Parameter format for info expect  but value='0x22f3250L'
```
Happy to hear that. Thanks for the advice.

Could you please try to test MNIST iter using this example? I find that the data layout of different iterator is different. We should try to consider all of them when implementing some general models.

For example, you used the provide_data and provide_label which are specific to NDArrayIter in solver.py. I think we should not use them.

@piiswrong I've found the problem. The bug is caused by https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/python/mxnet/operator.py#L202. Using `hex` for 16-bit string conversion will cause the [Trailing L Problem](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/5917203/python-trailing-l-problem) for 64-bit value. I've revised the code to

```
cb_ptr = format(cast(pointer(self.info_), c_void_p).value, 'x')
```

and it works well.
Thanks for the fix. Are you sure scanf("%p", &p) doesn't need the 0x in front? Could you open a PR for this?

`scanf("%p", &p)` will need the `0x` in front. 

In Julia I have to do `pstring = bytestring("0x", hex(reinterpret(UInt, pointer_from_objref(info))))` to get the correct value.
since you have `libcblas` and `libblas` you probablk have a netblas installed so you should set `USE_BLAS = atlas`. And then do `make clean && make` what error do you then get?
I think currently the blocking one is ROI pooling. If you could do it, and contribute a PR, that is the best.
The proposal progress is also needed to implement by writing two new operators, isn't?
@piiswrong @vchuravy I've made the pr and I'm not sure about the `scanf("%p", &p)` issue.
Yes, we definitely need them. However, they are relatively easier compare to ROI pooling,
I think ROI pooling is easier, because it gradient-free.
No, you need to back prop it as indicated in Fast RCNN paper.
Anyway, we need to implement them all before we can get it. You contribution is always welcomed :)

ROI pooling is actually the max pooling, definitely gradient-free(sure need backprop).
I think you didn't get my idea.:smile:

Hi,@zachmayer 

Just come back from the exam and fix this (see #560 ). Actually it is a very simple problem. We met an inconsistency of dimensions between R and the backend.

Now you should have something like below:

``` r
> library(mxnet)
> data(BostonHousing, package="mlbench")
> train.ind = seq(1, 506, 3)
> train.x = data.matrix(BostonHousing[train.ind, -14])
> train.y = BostonHousing[train.ind, 14]
> test.x = data.matrix(BostonHousing[-train.ind, -14])
> test.y = BostonHousing[-train.ind, 14]
> data <- mx.symbol.Variable("data")
> fc1 <- mx.symbol.FullyConnected(data, num_hidden=1)
> lro <- mx.symbol.LinearRegressionOutput(fc1)
> mx.set.seed(0)
> model <- mx.model.FeedForward.create(
+   lro, X=train.x, y=train.y,
+   ctx=mx.cpu(), num.round=50, array.batch.size=20,
+   learning.rate=2e-6, momentum=0.9, eval.metric=mx.metric.rmse)
Auto detect layout of input matrix, use rowmajor..
Start training with 1 devices
[1] Train-rmse=16.063282524034
[2] Train-rmse=12.2792375712573
[3] Train-rmse=11.1984634005885
[4] Train-rmse=10.2645236892904
......
```

Just let us know if you met new problems.

sorry, my English is poor that makes you misunderstand. Not the batch,it's the channel that n represent, the operation is just like pooling, one featur map corresponds to one same kernel，the output n feature map. Maybe convolution is not designed to handle operation of this type. So i wonder how to implement it.

@huazehuang , thanks for report this bug. i just test large image, i think the problem is that the defalut  workspace for convolution is too small when u using very large image, so i update the script create_vgg16fc_model.py  in  [fcn-xs example](https://github.com/tornadomeet/mxnet/tree/fcn-xs/example/fcn-xs), u can change workspace_default's value depenod on your image size;
now the big image can be predicted, when the input image size is (600, 600) and workspace=1024.
gitter added.

@tornadomeet Thanks for updating your code. 

The problem still exists. I have tried many large workspace size, but it didn't help. 

Did you try on GPU? In my case, increase workspace size can help to make it work on CPU, but not GPU.

Another strange thing is in [InitTemp function](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/68a25b2c4e5e26c12045d433fece8c6e4d9c9d2d/src/operator/convolution-inl.h#L252), it already checked if the workspace size can hold the convolution space.
@thirdwing can you check if this fixed the problem?

Of course!

Maybe we should also check the code in vignettes in travis.
I agree, maybe not run vignettes directly(some requires GPU)  but simply bring some of them into testcase.

I test it on both GPU and CPU, all passed. can you paste your test code?
For the InitTemp funciton, i also found it will be broken when the input image is too large. Though that was checked, it seems that we should configure the `workspace` when we construct the convulution symbol.

hmm, I think we want to debate whether it is good to put the work_load into the context class, or simply add it as a optional training parameter.

Also it might be bad to have a small batch for batchnormed network

Yes. I've also considered this. Adding the `work_load` into Context class might have influenced the the **abstract** of Context concept, since it's no use for data placement management. It's only used for training. 

However, I think the code in usage is more elegant for users to associate the `work_load` with the specific device, which is why I add the `work_load` to Context **abstract**.
It fixed the problem and I will update the travis scripts

The code is here [test example](https://github.com/huazehuang/mxnet/blob/fcn-xs/example/fcn-xs/test.py)

Thanks!

many thanks for the pr. the results are quite nice. 

i also suggest to add another argument beside `ctx` when creating the model rather than change the context, since it makes the python inconsistent with other lang bindings. adding the work_load to a device is nature, but it cannot extend to distributed training, where we need to manually partition the data.

btw, is there a way to query the gpu computational power so we can decide it automatically?

Received. I will remove the hack from Context and add an additional argument to solve the uneven load problem. 

For automatically query, I think it would be very complicated, since there's not a general formula to calculate the overall computational power of a GPU. Plus sometimes we also need to consider the usage of GPU memory. 

However, if you have different GPUs, I would suggest the following strategy to adjust your `work_load` assignment. 
1. `watch -n 1 nvidia-smi` to closely watch the usage of your GPUs. 
2. If you observe some GPU's `Volatile GPU-Util` periodically drop to 0% and then goes back to 99%. That means this GPU is waiting others to calculate and synchronize. So you need to add some work load to that GPU. 
3. If all GPU keep `99%` and steady, congratulations, you squeeze all the performance of your GPUs.

I recover the `Context` abstract to its origin and add the `work_load_list` argument to both `fit` and `create` function. For now, the usage is 

``` python
num_gpu = 3
gpus = [mx.gpu(i) for i in range(num_gpu)]
work_load_list = [10, 3, 10]

model = mx.model.FeedForward(ctx=gpus, symbol=softmax, num_epoch=num_epoch,
                             learning_rate=0.05, momentum=0.9, wd=0.00001)

model.fit(X=train, eval_data=val,
          eval_metric="acc",
          batch_end_callback=mx.callback.Speedometer(batch_size),
          epoch_end_callback=mx.callback.do_checkpoint(model_prefix),
          work_load_list=work_load_list)
```
I think a simple way of doing automatic query would be just run training loop for a few iterations and time it.
@piiswrong  I think it's a reasonable choice. Can we add GPU memory limit into consideration?  Since usually we want to set `batch_size` as large as possible to fit into the GPU memory.
I resolve this issue by disabling the cudnn and recompiling mxnet. Thanks for helping!

add and write should be the same if we update every batch, because the gradient is always accumulated before write to the gradient holder. 

The only difference was when doing update every two batches for example, then reset every two batch and with add will work differently than write

+1, if you check out the parameter in the IPython notebook, it says

```
update_period = 1
```

so add and write are the same here.
